bug.short_desc: Eclipse Public License should be available in DocBook

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 86433 EPL 1.0 in DocBook format
It would be nice if Eclipse included a version of the EPL 1.0 in docbook format. This way it could be easily included into documentation projects using DocBook for the content.
Attached is a version of the license in DocBook version 4.5 format. If this isn't the correct place for this issue, please move it.

Dave,
This does seem valuable.
Some questions:
- Our expectation is that we would place the DocBook formatted licenses on a well-known URL on our servers and basically leave them there. Is that correct?
- The EPL is only one license document at Eclipse. Would you be willing to help us by also providing the EDL and the Software User Agreement in DocBook format as well?

(In reply to comment #1) > Dave, > > This does seem valuable. > > Some questions: > > - Our expectation is that we would place the DocBook formatted licenses on a > well-known URL on our servers and basically leave them there. Is that correct?
Yes, or put it in CVS/SVN/GIT where it can be be versioned controlled and checked out as any other artifact.
> - The EPL is only one license document at Eclipse. Would you be willing to help > us by also providing the EDL and the Software User Agreement in DocBook format > as well?
Yeah, I can help get those into DocBook format as well. Just need examples of the various files. Nice thing about DocBook is that you can then generate the HTML, PDF, DITA, PDF, etc formats that the community may need.
Dave, are you waiting for something from us?
Sorry... more specifically, is there something I can do to help?

(In reply to comment #4) > Sorry... more specifically, is there something I can do to help?
Well, Provide me with the links to the files you want in DocBook format. Preferably the Text version or a version that has the various formatting.
Second review the file I attached for the EPL 1.0 is it correct or does it need additional information. You can use the VEX editor from the WTP Incubator to review it in a WYSIWYG view, or look at one of the commerical editors like XMLMind.
I'm traveling at the moment but will be back home next week so could work on this then. Just remind me as I have a lot of plates spinning at the moment.

(In reply to comment #5)
Hi Dave,
> Well, Provide me with the links to the files you want in DocBook format. > Preferably the Text version or a version that has the various formatting. >
Here are the URLs we have; I hope the format works for you. Plain HTML format links are on the far right hand side of each page.
Eclipse Software User Agreement: http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl/notice.php Eclipse Distribution License: http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/edl-v10.php
> Second review the file I attached for the EPL 1.0 is it correct or does it need > additional information. You can use the VEX editor from the WTP Incubator to > review it in a WYSIWYG view, or look at one of the commerical editors like > XMLMind.
Some nits and a few lines missing, as follows: _____________________________________________________
- "Defintion" should be enumerated, pluralized and in all caps: "1. DEFINITIONS"
----------------------------------------------
- the subsections under "Contribution" should be enumerated as follows:
a) in the case of the initial Contributor, the initial code and documentation distributed under this Agreement, and
b) in the case of each subsequent Contributor:
i) changes to the Program, and
ii) additions to the Program;
----------------------------------------------
- missing the definition of "Program" between "Licensed Patents" and "Recipient" as follows:
"Program" means the Contributions distributed in accordance with this Agreement.
----------------------------------------------
- the subsections under "2. GRANT OF RIGHTS" should be enumerated, and I believe the attachment is missing subsection (b) entirely, as follows:
a) Subject to the terms of this Agreement, each Contributor hereby grants Recipient a non-exclusive, worldwide, royalty-free copyright license to reproduce, prepare derivative works of, publicly display, publicly perform, distribute and sublicense the Contribution of such Contributor, if any, and such derivative works, in source code and object code form.
b) Subject to the terms of this Agreement, each Contributor hereby grants Recipient a non-exclusive, worldwide, royalty-free patent license under Licensed Patents to make, use, sell, offer to sell, import and otherwise transfer the Contribution of such Contributor, if any, in source code and object code form. This patent license shall apply to the combination of the Contribution and the Program if, at the time the Contribution is added by the Contributor, such addition of the Contribution causes such combination to be covered by the Licensed Patents. The patent license shall not apply to any other combinations which include the Contribution. No hardware per se is licensed hereunder.
c) Recipient understands that although each Contributor grants the licenses to its Contributions set forth herein, no assurances are provided by any Contributor that the Program does not infringe the patent or other intellectual property rights of any other entity. Each Contributor disclaims any liability to Recipient for claims brought by any other entity based on infringement of intellectual property rights or otherwise. As a condition to exercising the rights and licenses granted hereunder, each Recipient hereby assumes sole responsibility to secure any other intellectual property rights needed, if any. For example, if a third party patent license is required to allow Recipient to distribute the Program, it is Recipient's responsibility to acquire that license before distributing the Program.
d) Each Contributor represents that to its knowledge it has sufficient copyright rights in its Contribution, if any, to grant the copyright license set forth in this Agreement.
----------------------------------------------
- Section "3. Requirements" should be in all caps: "3. REQUIREMENTS"
----------------------------------------------
- subsections in Section 3 should be enumerated as follows:
A Contributor may choose to distribute the Program in object code form under its own license agreement, provided that:
a) it complies with the terms and conditions of this Agreement; and
b) its license agreement:
i) effectively disclaims on behalf of all Contributors all warranties and conditions, express and implied, including warranties or conditions of title and non-infringement, and implied warranties or conditions of merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose;
ii) effectively excludes on behalf of all Contributors all liability for damages, including direct, indirect, special, incidental and consequential damages, such as lost profits;
iii) states that any provisions which differ from this Agreement are offered by that Contributor alone and not by any other party; and
iv) states that source code for the Program is available from such Contributor, and informs licensees how to obtain it in a reasonable manner on or through a medium customarily used for software exchange.
When the Program is made available in source code form:
a) it must be made available under this Agreement; and
b) a copy of this Agreement must be included with each copy of the Program.
--------------------------------------------
- Section 4. Commercial Distribution should be in all caps: 4. COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION
---------------------------------------------
- Section 5. No Warranty should be in all caps: 5. NO WARRANTY
__________________________________________________________
If an HTML version of the EPL would help, there is one here: http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/epl-v10.html
If you want me to take a look at the respin, I'd be happy to do so.
> I'm traveling at the moment but will be back home next week so could work on > this then. Just remind me as I have a lot of plates spinning at the moment.
Well, it's been a while so maybe you've come home and you're traveling again! :-) You will be in a couple of weeks anyway.
Thanks for your patience, Dave!

Just a couple of comments.
In regards to specific headers being captialized. That should be left out of the DocBook text. The reason being is that is styling and formatting which is separate from the text. The DocBook format is all about content. Now we could create some extensions for DocBook XSL so that it styles it the way you want, or we make notes that if the DocBook file is used, then certain sections need to have specific styling applied in order to be compliant.
I'll see what I can do with this over the next couple of weeks.

Okay....food for thought as you think on this some more then....it would be our preference to have the headers capitalized if at all possible. Some section headers *look* to be capitalized in the view I have.
If you take a look at the HTML copy of the EPL, you'll see some of the contents in Section 5 and 6 in all caps. Some US legislation requires that remain in all caps, so we are obligated to comply for those pieces.
Perhaps I don't understand the pain points...?

(In reply to comment #8) > Okay....food for thought as you think on this some more then....it would be our > preference to have the headers capitalized if at all possible. Some section > headers *look* to be capitalized in the view I have. > > If you take a look at the HTML copy of the EPL, you'll see some of the contents > in Section 5 and 6 in all caps. Some US legislation requires that remain in > all caps, so we are obligated to comply for those pieces. > > Perhaps I don't understand the pain points...? Oh I can always type the letters in capital letters, but DocBook is all about content, how it is styled is a seperate item. For example, let's take the HTML as an example. With a CSS stylesheet, one can specify that all h2 elements should have all letters uppercase: h2 {text-transform:uppercase} So when the HTML is displayed by a CSS processor it can manipulate the text. So that even if it comes in as:

some where over the rainbow

It'll be output as: SOME WHERE OVER THE RAINBOW The same can happen with lowercase letters as well: h2 {text-transform:lowercase}

SOME WHERE OVER THE RAINBOW

Will be transformed into: some where over the rainbow It's the seperation of style from content that I was talking about. With DocBook you can do something similar when it is actually processed into HTML, PDF, or whatever format. Styling is applied at the time of processing. Stuff like OrderedLists, UnorderedLists, etc, can be done...and I can go through an enter items in Uppercase where you need it to be that way. But I also suggest that guidelines accompy the use of even the HTML version so that somebody's stylesheet doesn't over ride the style that is required.

(In reply to comment #9) Hi Dave,
Just following up....are you expecting something more from us at this point?
Thanks.
Barb

(In reply to comment #10) > (In reply to comment #9) > Hi Dave, > > Just following up....are you expecting something more from us at this point? > > Thanks. > > Barb
Nope...just an invention of a Time Machine so I can freeze time. I may have some time this weekend to work on it.

(In reply to comment #10) > (In reply to comment #9) > Hi Dave, > > Just following up....are you expecting something more from us at this point? > > Thanks. > > Barb
Barb, I'm attaching an updated and cleaned up version of the document with a sample HTML produced version. The html was produced by using a set of XSL stylesheets, and used the DocBook XML file as input to the process.
Created attachment 162931 Updated DocBook version of the EPL document.

Created attachment 162932 Sample HTML file single-sourced from DocBook EPL file
The HTML file attached shows a sample of how this could be rendered from the DocBook XML file attached. I provide it as an visual sample to better communicate the separation between content and presentation.

Created attachment 162933 HTML generated version with Sections numbered.
This version shows the <section> tags when rendered in HTML with section numbers.

Created attachment 162934 No table of Contents in HTML
This version is generated so no table of contents is produced, but there are section numbers. Parameters to the DocBook XSL stylesheets from the DocBook project (
section.autolable 1 generate.toc chapter nop
http://docbook.sourceforge.net/

With the docbook version I can now produce PDF, HTML, and other formats from one single source file. Make a change to the DocBook file and it propogates to the other generated versions.
Barb let me know if I have anything I still need to tweak.

Thanks Dave; we'll get back to you next week after Janet gets back from EclipseCon.
Hope you (and your cat ;-)) had a great time there!
Cheers,
Barb

Hi Dave,
I have to preface my comments with a *big thank you*, and an admission that I feel a bit (well, more than a bit :-)) uncomfortable asking for any more tweaks because you've been so generous with your time. If the changes we ask for are starting to feel like a never-ending drip, we'll certainly understand if you need to focus your priorities elsewhere.
I think one of the things you are asking is which version we would prefer, and attachment162934 (with section numbers and without ToC) is the hands-down winner. It most closely resembles the version we maintain.
That said, we have three questions related to the "winner":
1. There are a couple of definitions missing from the first section. Specifically:
"Licensed Patents" mean patent claims licensable by a Contributor which are necessarily infringed by the use or sale of its Contribution alone or when combined with the Program.
"Program" means the Contributions distributed in accordance with this Agreement.
They fit between "Contributor" and "Recipient". Is that an easy fix?
2. Because some people (e.g. legal folks) pay a lot of attention to detail, it's probably best that the DocBook version of the license look as identical as possible to the one we maintain. Otherwise people could start to wonder what else might be different. With that logic in mind, the primary sections are appropriately enumerated and the punctuation marks (which are periods ".") match. However, while subsections in the "winner" are appropriately enumerated, their punctuation marks are slightly different than in the EPL we maintain: we use a bracket in the subsections ")" while the "winner" uses a period ".". Would it be possible to replace the subsection punctuation?
3. Can you help us understand how / why the Chapter number would be applied at the top?
It might help you to see a redline version of the differences Dave. I'll pull one together and send it to you via email.
Again, any time this feels like too much, just say the word.
Cheers,
Barb

(In reply to comment #19) > Hi Dave, > > I have to preface my comments with a *big thank you*, and an admission that I > feel a bit (well, more than a bit :-)) uncomfortable asking for any more tweaks > because you've been so generous with your time. If the changes we ask for are > starting to feel like a never-ending drip, we'll certainly understand if you > need to focus your priorities elsewhere. > > I think one of the things you are asking is which version we would prefer, and > attachment162934 [details] (with section numbers and without ToC) is the hands-down > winner. It most closely resembles the version we maintain.
There are no changes needed for the DocBook file to make happen. That is just one of the ways that using the DocBook XSL stylesheets that items can be rendered.
> > That said, we have three questions related to the "winner": > > 1. There are a couple of definitions missing from the first section. > Specifically: > > "Licensed Patents" mean patent claims licensable by a Contributor which are > necessarily infringed by the use or sale of its Contribution alone or when > combined with the Program. > > "Program" means the Contributions distributed in accordance with this > Agreement.
Okay, I've updated the DocBook file with these. Changes.
> 2. Because some people (e.g. legal folks) pay a lot of attention to detail, > it's probably best that the DocBook version of the license look as identical as > possible to the one we maintain. Otherwise people could start to wonder what > else might be different. With that logic in mind, the primary sections are > appropriately enumerated and the punctuation marks (which are periods ".") > match. However, while subsections in the "winner" are appropriately > enumerated, their punctuation marks are slightly different than in the EPL we > maintain: we use a bracket in the subsections ")" while the "winner" uses a > period ".". Would it be possible to replace the subsection punctuation?
This is a styling thing, and should be noted for when people want to include the DocBook file in their documentation. We should open a separate bug to address the modifications or customization layer that needs to be done with the stylesheets from the "The DocBook Project"
http://docbook.sourceforge.net/
See also, Docbook XSL: The Complete Guide (http://www.sagehill.net/docbookxsl/) and DocBook: The Definitive Guide (http://www.docbook.org/tdg/)
> > 3. Can you help us understand how / why the Chapter number would be applied at > the top?
It's just the default. If this is included in a Preface/Chapter/Appendix, etc, Chapter numbers can be applied when styling the content. If that is not what is needed for how this should be rendered, then we can setup custom styling for this in a separate bug that addresses styling.
One thing I think we need to keep in mind on this particular bug, is that we are dealing with two separate issues. The DocBook file itself is about the content, and some of the other items you are addressing have to do with how it is rendered/styled. These are two separate items.
I'll attach an updated docbook file, and open a separate bug where we can address styling information.
BTW, you can use the Vex editor plugin within eclipse to view the content in a WYSIWYG type fashion. In the styling bug we could come up with a CSS stylesheet for Vex that renders it as closely as possible within the editor to how you would expect it to be viewed.
Created attachment 163421 DocBook version with latest changes.

Created attachment 163423 No Table of Contents and No Chapter Numbers
Here is a sample rendered with No Table ofContents and No Chapter numbers. We should continue discussion of Styling of the DocBook file in bug 307556.
I can work on creating the End User Agreement and other files, if we are good with the content of the current DocBook file.
Just following up if you have had a chance to review the updated versions. I'll probably start on the End user Agreement and the EDL files next.

Sorry Dave, but no I haven't.....we've had a spike in CQ requests in IPZilla and have had to focus our efforts on triage over there.
I'll try to get to it this week though!
Thanks!
Cheers,
Barb

Unfortunately I won't be able to get to this review today as I'd hoped; CQ requests spiked up significantly yesterday and we have to focus our attention there, at least until we determine whether we can give them checkintocvs under parallel IP.
My new target date for review of this bug is Wednesday the 21st.

(In reply to comment #25) > Unfortunately I won't be able to get to this review today as I'd hoped; CQ > requests spiked up significantly yesterday and we have to focus our attention > there, at least until we determine whether we can give them checkintocvs under > parallel IP. > > My new target date for review of this bug is Wednesday the 21st.
Ping!

Created attachment 179962 Comparison of Eclipse's EPL on our URL against the most recent version Dave submitted
Hi Dave,
Sorry for the delay; we've been swamped in IPZilla-land. [insert juggling person icon here]
For the sake of consistency and for legal reasons as well, the document needs to be a mirror copy of the EPL from both a content and style perspective. I understand you opened another bug for style, but I'll just put all my comments here for ease of reference.
a) content - definition of "Contributor" needs to be moved to the spot where it originally occurs b) brackets versus periods c) indentations and spacing
I've attached a document that will show you what I mean by a) and b). Unfortunately, it does not address c). You will have to do an eyeball comparison against our link to get a mirror view of that. For your reference, here is the html link to the EPL: http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/epl-v10.html

> c) indentations and spacing > > I've attached a document that will show you what I mean by a) and b). > Unfortunately, it does not address c). You will have to do an eyeball > comparison against our link to get a mirror view of that. For your reference, > here is the html link to the EPL: > http://www.eclipse.org/org/documents/epl-v10.html
Indentations and spacing is a styling thing. as well as the brackets versus periods.
The contribution I'll move around.

Created attachment 179965 Moved Contributor definition and tweaked other items.
Moved the items and updated the version information.

(In reply to comment #29) > Created an attachment (id=179965) [details] > Moved Contributor definition and tweaked other items. > > Moved the items and updated the version information.
Hi Dave,
Can you please provide it in the same format as you did for attachment163423? It's much more difficult (for me) to confirm content by looking at xml.
Thanks.

Created attachment 179970 Updated generated HTML version
Notice that this still contains the styling issues mentioned previously.

Okay I see "Contributor" has been moved...thanks.
As for styling, in comment 20, does the nut of that comment mean that we cannot set the style, rather we provide instructions on what the style is meant to be and then people who use Docbook may choose to mirror that style or not?
For avoidance of doubt, we would prefer that the style is set and that it is not modifiable. Does achieving that objective mean that one of us will have to become familiar with DocBook?
I'll stop asking questions now.... :)

(In reply to comment #32) > Okay I see "Contributor" has been moved...thanks. > > As for styling, in comment 20, does the nut of that comment mean that we cannot > set the style, rather we provide instructions on what the style is meant to be > and then people who use Docbook may choose to mirror that style or not?
See below for more info, but yes, you would need to provide instructions. We can provide a sample XSL stylesheet that leverages the DocBook XSL projects content, but it would be a sample only. As further customization has to take place depending on the target medium that the content is being generated too.
> > For avoidance of doubt, we would prefer that the style is set and that it is > not modifiable. Does achieving that objective mean that one of us will have to > become familiar with DocBook?
Well, what you can do is provide your own DocBook XSL customization layer that sets the styling. But Docbook is all about content not about how it is rendered. This is so that it can be generated to HTML, ePub, Web Help, Eclipse Help, Wiki, PDF, Word, etc. How it is rendered is dependent on the particular output format.
I can help with creating the default stylsheet to be used if people are generating say to HTML and possibly PDF, but you should also provide instructions on requirements for rendering this.
This is no different than if the EPL document is put in DITA format, Word Format, Open Document Format, etc. You still need the rules around it, in how it should be styled for those target document formats.

I'm impressed and overwhelmed at the same time!
I think it's safe to say the level of effort is more than I anticipated. Since it will affect some other priorities we have on our plate, I think I'll need to re-group with the team until we go any further. Let's put this in a holding pattern until we've done that. I'll update the bug by the end of next week.
Thanks Dave.

(In reply to comment #34) > I'm impressed and overwhelmed at the same time! > > I think it's safe to say the level of effort is more than I anticipated. Since > it will affect some other priorities we have on our plate, I think I'll need to > re-group with the team until we go any further. Let's put this in a holding > pattern until we've done that. I'll update the bug by the end of next week. > > Thanks Dave.
BTW, you can view and edit the DocBook file using the Eclipse Vex incubator project. Plugins installable from here:
https://hudson.eclipse.org/hudson/view/WTP/job/cbi-wtp-inc.vex/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/sourceediting/development/org.eclipse.wst.xml.vex.repository/target/site/

Hi Dave,
Looks like I'm not going to be able to talk to the stakeholders I need to this week; I'm aiming for next week now so I'll give you an update then. Just wanted you to know it hasn't fallen off my radar.
Thanks.
Barb

Hi Dave,
No definitive news, but a quick update. This bug was the subject of some discussion last week. Stakeholders are weighing competing priorities to see how this fits in queue. Be back soon. Thanks for your patience.
Barb

Hi Dave,
Quick update; we haven't forgotten about you! There is still an ongoing discussion regarding this activity; Wayne has taken this under consideration and he/we will be updating this bug as soon as a definitive decision has been made.
Thanks!
Barb

(In reply to comment #38) > Hi Dave, > > Quick update; we haven't forgotten about you! There is still an ongoing > discussion regarding this activity; Wayne has taken this under consideration > and he/we will be updating this bug as soon as a definitive decision has been > made.
Thanks Barb. No rush from my end, just think it would be good for the adopters to have something in something besides an HTML format, along with some requirements on how they should style it because of legal requirements.

I intuitively think that this will be useful. I understand the intrinsic value of flexibility. Others have stated that they believe that there is value in having the licenses (and other documents) in other formats. Nobody, however, has given any specifics. Can anybody cite *specific* examples of where and how this will be beneficial to the community? e.g. in what context would it be critical to have the EPL in PDF format? How would the output generated from DocBook format be better than a PDF generated directly from the HTML using htmldoc?
Sorry to be hard-line about this, but I have been asked justify the IP Team's investment in this at a time when they are already overburdened.
It is also the case that when we have these documents in DocBook format, that format then has to be the "source" format. It makes no sense to edit documents in both their "original" HTML and DocBook. All editing should henceforth be effected in the DocBook files and the HTML generated. While I understand that these documents do not tend to change, there may be future versions of the licenses that we'll need to edit. Also, we are establishing a precedent with this. Are we (i.e. the Eclipse Foundation) prepared to start investing in the use of DocBook in place of, say, MS Word for those documents that we currently render as PDF?
Is the IP Team prepared to invest in the (albeit relatively small) effort required to learn how to edit DocBook at some (probably far) future date?
FWIW, I am a big fan of using DocBook for articles and books. We have several articles in this format; it is very handy when I need to make format changes. Also, simply as a data-point, I generated the PDF version of the EPL [1] from the original HTML using htmldoc.
[1] http://www.eclipse.org/projects/dev_process/development_process_2010.pdf

(In reply to comment #40) > I intuitively think that this will be useful. I understand the intrinsic value > of flexibility. Others have stated that they believe that there is value in > having the licenses (and other documents) in other formats. Nobody, however, > has given any specifics. Can anybody cite *specific* examples of where and how > this will be beneficial to the community? e.g. in what context would it be > critical to have the EPL in PDF format? How would the output generated from > DocBook format be better than a PDF generated directly from the HTML using > htmldoc?
Sure, I can show you some specific examples. I still do some consulting for STAR (www.starstandards.org), their standards are licensed under the eclipse public license. They need to generate their documentation in multiple formats. So need to include licensing information with in the documentation itself (it's a requirement from them). Because they need to generate the documentation in multiple formats (HTML, PDF, Eclipse Help, RTF, etc). They use DocBook as the medium to do this.
To this end they have a version of the EPL that was converted to Docbook. You can see the HTML and PDF versions of these guidelines and their usage:
http://www.starstandard.org/guidelines/STAR534/BOD/pr01s02.html
http://www.starstandard.org/uploads/SIGXMLSTAR5/BOD.pdf
Generation of end user documentation can appear in multiple formats, including ePub, PDF, HTML, DOC, RTF, ODT, etc.
using the xml include specification the official eclipse docbook file could be included and used and embedded with in the document. It would be up to adopters and people including the license in embedded documentation to make sure they follow the legal styling requirements.
> > Sorry to be hard-line about this, but I have been asked justify the IP Team's > investment in this at a time when they are already overburdened. > > It is also the case that when we have these documents in DocBook format, that > format then has to be the "source" format. It makes no sense to edit documents > in both their "original" HTML and DocBook. All editing should henceforth be > effected in the DocBook files and the HTML generated. While I understand that > these documents do not tend to change, there may be future versions of the > licenses that we'll need to edit. Also, we are establishing a precedent with > this. Are we (i.e. the Eclipse Foundation) prepared to start investing in the > use of DocBook in place of, say, MS Word for those documents that we currently > render as PDF? > > Is the IP Team prepared to invest in the (albeit relatively small) effort > required to learn how to edit DocBook at some (probably far) future date?
Well, that is where I HOPE that the Vex editor can come into play a bit. Since it is in proposal phase it is built into eclipse, and provides the WYSIWYG type editing people want for these documents.
*** Bug 349815 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created attachment 198314 Eclipse Foundation Software User Agreement in DocBook XML format (as of Feb 1st 2011)
As stated in bug 349815 this attachment contains the EPL as of February 1, 2011 in DocBook XML format version 4.5.
This content is added in relation to the discussion in the Eclipse Community Forum at http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php/t/208559/ where such a document has been requested.
The content is based upon: http://www.eclipse.org/legal/epl/notice.html changes consist of changed xml tags and the translation of HTML entities to their DocBook counterparts. The formatting has been preserved to allow easy comparison to the original document.
Created attachment 198384 Eclipse Foundation Software User Agreement in DocBook xml format
Created attachment 198385 Eclipse Foundation Software User Agreement - Exemplary HTML Rendering

Created attachment 198386 Eclipse Foundation Software User Agreement - Exemplary PDF Rendering
Added DocBook Source and exemplary HTML/PDF Rendering of the Eclipse Foundation Software User Agreement.
